hero.title: Immigration Guidance Services for Your Future

intro.title: Your ally in immigration processes
intro.description: Our specialized consultants provide personalized support for all your immigration needs, facilitating your path to U.S. residency. We work with USCIS requirements, ensuring your applications meet all established parameters.

serviceItems.title: U.S. Citizenship
serviceItems.description: We assist with Form N-400 for a smooth naturalization process.
serviceItems.content: Form N-400: Application for U.S. Citizenship
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: To apply for U.S. citizenship, you must have been a permanent resident (Green Card holder) for at least 5 years. If married to a U.S. citizen, this period is reduced to 3 years. During this time, you must have maintained continuous residence in the United States.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText: You must have been physically present in the U.S. for at least 30 months of the last 5 years before applying. If married to a U.S. citizen, the requirement is 18 months of the last 3 years.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText: It's essential to demonstrate good conduct during the required residency period. This includes paying taxes, complying with U.S. laws, and having no relevant criminal record. USCIS will evaluate your conduct during this period.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText: The final stage includes taking the Oath of Allegiance to the United States. By doing so, you express your commitment to the country and its laws.
serviceItems.contentFinal: If you meet these basic requirements, we can begin the process with Form N-400 to start your path to U.S. citizenship.

serviceItems.title: Work Permit (EAD)
serviceItems.description: We guide you through Form I-765 to obtain your Employment Authorization Document.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Document authorizing legal employment in the United States
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: The Employment Authorization Document (EAD) is a work permit issued by USCIS that certifies your legal right to work in the U.S. It's obtained through Form I-765 and contains your personal information, immigration category, and validity period.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
Individuals who need to work legally in the U.S. but aren't citizens or permanent residents, including:
- Asylum applicants
- Students in certain categories
- People in the process of adjusting status
- Temporary protection beneficiaries
- Family members of specific visa holders
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Initial application: First time
2. Renewal: Submit up to 120 days before expiration
3. Replacement: For lost or damaged documents

Process: Submit Form I-765 to receive temporary authorization (duration varies based on your immigration status). Approval allows you to work for any employer.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
- Legal employment authorization
- No restrictions on specific employers
- Valid document for hiring processes
- Work flexibility

Important: Processing times may vary. We recommend starting renewals in advance.
serviceItems.contentFinal: For updated information on requirements and processing times, always check official USCIS sources.

serviceItems.title: Permanent Residency (Green Card)
serviceItems.description: We advise on Form I-485 to adjust your status to permanent resident.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Green Card application from within the U.S.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: Form I-485 allows certain individuals in the U.S. to change their immigration status to permanent resident (obtain a Green Card). It must be filed with USCIS and is available to those who meet the established requirements.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
1. Physical presence in the U.S.
2. Approved immigration petition (except in certain cases)
3. Visa availability based on category
4. Compliance with immigration requirements
5. Eligibility to enter/remain in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Family: Spouses, parents, or children of U.S. citizens
2. Employment: Sponsored by employer
3. Special cases: Asylum, special protection, among others

*Individuals outside the U.S. must follow different processes
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Benefits:
- Ability to work with authorization while processing
- Option to travel with prior authorization
- Path to citizenship (after 3-5 years)

Process:
1. Submit I-485 + documentation
2. Attend biometrics appointment
3. Interview (in most cases)
4. Final USCIS decision
serviceItems.contentFinal: For detailed information on specific requirements and necessary documentation, check official sources or request specialized advice.

serviceItems.title: Visa Advisory
serviceItems.description: Professional assistance with Form DS-160 for B1/B2 visitor visas (business or tourism).
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Online process for business (B1) or tourism (B2) visas
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
The DS-160 is the electronic form required to apply for:

‚Ä¢ Business visas (B1)
‚Ä¢ Tourism visas (B2)
‚Ä¢ Combined B1/B2 visas

It must be completed before scheduling the consulate interview.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
Main requirements:

1. Valid passport (minimum 6 months validity)
2. Recent digital photo (5x5 cm, white background)
3. Travel itinerary (flight tickets, hotel reservations)
4. Proof of ties to your home country
5. For B1: Company letter explaining travel purpose
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. **Complete the DS-160** online:
   - Personal information
   - Travel history
   - Employment data
   - U.S. contacts

2. **Pay the MRV fee** ($160 USD)

3. **Schedule interview** at the consulate

4. **Attend appointment** with all documentation
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
To improve your approval chances:

‚Ä¢ Carefully verify all information
‚Ä¢ Answers must match your documentation
‚Ä¢ Prepare for the interview:
  - Clearly explain your travel purpose
  - Demonstrate you'll return to your country
  - Bring original documents and copies

‚Ä¢ Avoid mentioning interest in working or studying
serviceItems.contentFinal: Note: Completing the DS-160 doesn't guarantee visa approval. The final decision is made by the consular officer during the interview. Average processing time: 2-3 weeks.

serviceItems.title: Family Reunification
serviceItems.description: Guidance for permanent residency for family members with Form I-130.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Help your relative obtain permanent residency in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-130 is used to:

‚Ä¢ Establish a valid family relationship
‚Ä¢ Initiate the family immigration process
‚Ä¢ Obtain a visa number for eligible relatives

It's the first step for your relative to obtain their residency.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
U.S. Citizens Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Parents
- Children (any age/marital status)
- Siblings

Permanent Residents Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Unmarried children (any age)

Important: A separate I-130 form is required for each relative.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Essential documents:

1. Proof of your immigration status:
   - Birth certificate (citizens)
   - Naturalization certificate
   - Permanent residency (Green Card)

2. Proof of family relationship:
   - Marriage certificate
   - Birth certificates
   - Adoption documents

3. Evidence of financial support (for subsequent Form I-864)
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
1. File Form I-130 with USCIS
2. Wait for petition approval
3. Relative processes the visa:
   - From abroad: Consular process
   - In the U.S.: Status adjustment (Form I-485)

Processing Times:
‚Ä¢ Immediate relatives: No waiting list
‚Ä¢ Other cases: Varies by category/country (1-10+ years)

Note: All applicants must meet medical and background requirements
serviceItems.contentFinal: Notice: I-130 approval doesn't guarantee the visa. Your relative must meet all requirements. We recommend professional guidance for complex cases.

serviceItems.title: DACA Renewal
serviceItems.description: Advisory to renew your DACA status with Form I-821D.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Temporary protection for eligible individuals who arrived in the U.S. as minors
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
‚Ä¢ Renewals Only: Currently only DACA renewals are processed
‚Ä¢ No New Applications: Initial applications aren't accepted
‚Ä¢ Limited Window: Only those with status expiring between September 2017 and March 2018 can renew

Important: Those who never had DACA cannot currently apply
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify for DACA you need:

1. Arrived in the U.S. before age 16
2. Were under 31 years old as of June 15, 2012
3. Lived continuously in the U.S. since June 2007
4. Were present in the U.S. on June 15, 2012
5. Had no regularized immigration status in June 2012
6. Meet education/military requirements:
   - Currently studying OR
   - Have a high school diploma/GED OR
   - Are an honorably discharged veteran
7. Have no serious criminal record
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Required evidence:

‚Ä¢ Identification:
  - Passport/birth certificate
  - Official IDs

‚Ä¢ Proof of Continuous Residence:
  - School/medical records
  - Employment history
  - Bank statements

‚Ä¢ Educational/Military Proof:
  - Diplomas/transcripts
  - GED certificate
  - Military service documents
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
For eligible renewals:

1. Submit Form I-821D
2. Send Form I-765 for work permit
3. Pay $495 fee
4. Provide biometric data
5. Wait for USCIS processing

Processing Time: Typically 4-6 months

Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work permit
‚Ä¢ Social Security Number

Note: DACA does NOT provide:
‚Ä¢ Permanent residency
‚Ä¢ Path to citizenship
‚Ä¢ Access to federal financial aid
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: If your DACA expired after March 2018, seek professional guidance. Policy changes may affect program availability - check USCIS website for updates before applying.

serviceItems.title: Immigration Protection
serviceItems.description: Advisory with Form I-589 for international protection applicants.
serviceItems.content: Protection in the U.S. Due to Persecution in Your Country
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Immigration process for individuals who fear returning to their home country
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-589 has three main functions:

‚Ä¢ Application for permanent protection
‚Ä¢ Petition to avoid deportation
‚Ä¢ Protection under international agreements

It's the main form to seek protection in the U.S. due to persecution reasons.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify you need:

1. Demonstrate real risk of persecution due to:
   - Race/Religion
   - Nationality
   - Political opinion
   - Membership in social group

2. Be physically present in the U.S. (regardless of how you entered)
3. File within 1 year of arrival (with exceptions for special cases)
4. Not have:
   - Previous deportation orders
   - Previously denied applications
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Required evidence:

‚Ä¢ Completed Form I-589
‚Ä¢ Detailed personal statement:
  - Specific persecution incidents
  - Situation in your country
  - Reasons you can't return

‚Ä¢ Supporting evidence:
  - Medical/psychological reports
  - Police reports
  - Relevant news
  - Witness statements
  - Certified document translations

‚Ä¢ Two passport-style photos
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Filing Steps:
1. Complete and sign Form I-589
2. Gather supporting evidence
3. Submit to USCIS
4. Attend biometrics appointment
5. Interview with officer
6. Receive decision

Potential Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work permit
‚Ä¢ Possibility of permanent residency
‚Ä¢ Family reunification
‚Ä¢ Access to basic services
serviceItems.contentFinal:
Recommendation: International protection cases are complex. It's highly recommended to:
‚Ä¢ Seek professional guidance
‚Ä¢ File within the 1-year deadline
‚Ä¢ Provide clear and consistent evidence
‚Ä¢ Check USCIS processing times

serviceItems.title: Citizenship by Descent
serviceItems.description: Guidance to establish your status with Form N-600.
serviceItems.content: Certificate of U.S. Citizenship: Form N-600
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Individuals born abroad to U.S. citizen parents may have automatically obtained citizenship. Form N-600 documents this status based on ancestry.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
You can file Form N-600 if:
‚Ä¢ You claim U.S. citizenship by law while in the U.S.
‚Ä¢ You were born abroad to U.S. citizen parents.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
You obtain automatic citizenship if you meet:
- Citizen Parent: At least one parent is a citizen by birth or naturalization.
- U.S. Residence: You live in the U.S. with your citizen parent.
- Legal Permanent Resident: You were legally admitted as a resident.
- Minor: You're under 18 years old.
- Legal Custody: You were under legal custody of citizen parent before turning 16.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
You can claim citizenship at birth if:
- Both parents are citizens, and one resided in the U.S. before your birth.
- Or, if one parent is foreign and the other is a citizen who was in the U.S. at least 5 years (2 after age 14).
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
You can also apply if before turning 18 and before 02/27/2001:
- You lived continuously in the U.S. as a legal permanent resident; and
- Your parents or custodial parent naturalized as citizens.
serviceItems.contentFivePointText: For minors under 18 who meet requirements, the application must be filed by the citizen parent or legal guardian with custody.
serviceItems.contentSixPointText: To begin the process, complete and submit Form N-600 with documentation proving you meet the criteria. This certificate serves as official proof of your U.S. citizenship.
